text: (An-Nasa'i and Al-Hakim) He used to say: (Allah Mighty and Majestic has not revealed in the Torah nor in the Gospel anything like the Mother of the Quran; it is the Seven Oft-Repeated Verses [and the Great Quran which I have been given].) (Al-Bukhari). And he (peace be upon him) commanded the one who prayed badly to recite it in his prayer (Abu Dawood, Ibn Khuzaymah, Al-Hakim, and others). And he said to the one who could not memorize it: (Say: Subhan Allah, wal-Hamdu Lillah, wa La ilaha illa Allah, wallahu Akbar, wa La Hawla wa La Quwwata illa Billah - Glory be to Allah, Praise be to Allah, There is no deity but Allah, Allah is the Greatest, and there is no power nor strength except by Allah) (Abu Dawood and At-Tirmidhi, and he classified it as Hasan). And he said to the one who prayed badly: (If you have some Quran, recite it; otherwise, praise Allah, magnify Him, and declare His Oneness). Abrogation of reciting behind the Imam in loud prayers.

text: (Al-Bukhari in a suspended form and At-Tirmidhi connected it and classified it as Sahih) (And [there was a man from the Ansar who used to lead them in the mosque of (Quba), and every time he began a Surah which he would recite for them in the prayer, he would start with 'Qul Huwa Allahu Ahad' until he finished it, then he would recite another Surah with it. He used to do that in every Rak'ah. His companions spoke to him and said: 'You start with this Surah, then you do not think it is sufficient for you until you recite another. Either you recite it or you leave it and recite another.' He said: 'I will not leave it. If you like me to lead you with it, I will do so; and if you dislike it, I will leave you.' They considered him to be one of their best, and they disliked having anyone else lead them. When the Prophet (peace be upon him) came to them, they informed him of the news. He said: (O so-and-so, what prevents you from doing what your companions command you, and what makes you adhere to this Surah in every Rak'ah?) He said: 'I love it.' He said: (Your love for it has admitted you into Paradise). Combining similar Surahs and others in one Rak'ah.

text: First Introduction of the Book: Praise be to Allah who ordained the prayer upon His servants and commanded them to establish it and perform it well, and linked success and prosperity to humility (Khushoo) within it, and made it a criterion between faith and disbelief, and a deterrent from immorality and wrongdoing. Blessings and peace be upon our Prophet Muhammad, who was addressed by the Almighty's saying: {And We revealed to you the message that you may make clear to the people what was sent down to them} [An-Nahl: 44]. So he (peace and blessings be upon him) fulfilled this duty in the truest sense, and the prayer was among the greatest of what he clarified to the people by word and deed, to the extent that he once prayed on the pulpit—standing, bowing on it—and then said to them: (I have done this only so that you may follow me and learn my prayer) (Al-Bukhari and Muslim). He made it obligatory for us to follow him in it, saying: (Pray as you have seen me pray) (Al-Bukhari and Muslim). And he gave glad tidings to the one who prays it like his prayer that he has a covenant with Allah to enter Paradise, saying: (Sahih Abi Dawud) (Five prayers which Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, has obligated; whoever performs their ablution well, prays them at their times, and perfects their bowing, prostration, and humility, has a covenant with Allah that He will forgive him. And whoever does not do so, has no covenant with Allah; if He wills, He forgives him, and if He wills, He punishes him).

To proceed: When I finished reading the 'Book of Prayer' from 'At-Targhib wat-Tarhib' by Al-Hafiz Al-Mundhiri (may Allah have mercy on him) and teaching it to some of our Salafi brothers—this was four years ago—it became clear to us all the high status and position prayer holds in Islam, and the reward, virtue, and honor for the one who establishes it and performs it well. It also became clear that this varies—increasing and decreasing—in proportion to its closeness to or distance from the prayer of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him), as he indicated in his saying (Sahih Abi Dawud): (Verily, a servant performs the prayer, yet nothing is written for him of it except a tenth, a ninth, an eighth, a seventh, a sixth, a fifth, a quarter, a third, or half of it). Therefore, I alerted the brothers that we cannot perform it perfectly—or close to it—unless we know the description of the Prophet's prayer (peace and blessings be upon him) in detail, including its: obligations, etiquettes, forms, supplications, and remembrances, and then strive to apply that practically. Only then can we hope that our prayer will restrain us from immorality and wrongdoing, and that the reward and recompense mentioned regarding it will be written for us.

text: Reason for Authoring the Book: Since I did not find a comprehensive book on this subject, I saw it as a duty upon myself to compile for my Muslim brothers—those whose concern is to follow the guidance of their Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) in their worship—a book covering as much as possible of everything related to the description of the Prophet's prayer (peace and blessings be upon him) from the Takbeer to the Tasleem. This is to make it easy for those who read it—among those who truly love the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him)—to fulfill his command in the aforementioned hadith: (Pray as you have seen me pray). For this reason, I rolled up my sleeves and tracked down the hadiths related to my objective from various books of Hadith. The result was this book which is in your hands. I stipulated upon myself not to include in it any Prophetic hadiths except those with an established chain of narration according to the rules and principles of the noble Science of Hadith. I disregarded everything isolated by an unknown or weak narrator, whether regarding forms, remembrances, virtues, or otherwise, because I believe that the authentic hadiths offer sufficiency over the weak ones. For the weak [hadith] conveys nothing—without dispute—except conjecture, and mere conjecture, as the Almighty said: {It does not avail against the truth at all}. And the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said: (Beware of suspicion/conjecture, for suspicion is the falsest of speech) (Al-Bukhari and Muslim). Thus, Allah Almighty did not assign us to worship Him by acting upon it; rather, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) forbade us from it, saying:

And Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, says: {O you who have believed, respond to Allah and to the Messenger when he calls you to that which gives you life. And know that Allah intervenes between a man and his heart and that to Him you will be gathered} [Al-Anfal: 24]. And Allah speaks the truth, and He guides to the path. He is the Best Protector and the Best Helper. And blessings and peace of Allah be upon Muhammad and upon his family and companions. And praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds. Damascus 20 / 5 / 1381 AH. Muhammad Nasir al-Din al-Albani.

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer from the Takbeer to the Tasleem as if You See It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Facing the Kaaba: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) used to face the Kaaba when standing for prayer in both obligatory and voluntary prayers, and he commanded that, saying to the (one who prayed badly): (Al-Bukhari and Muslim) (If you stand for prayer, perform ablution well, then face the Qiblah and say Takbeer) (Al-Bukhari and Muslim). And (he (peace and blessings be upon him) used to pray voluntary prayers on his mount during travel and perform Witr on it wherever it faced [east or west]) (Muslim). Regarding this, the Almighty's saying was revealed: {So wherever you [might] turn, there is the Face of Allah} [Al-Baqarah: 115] (Abu Dawud and Ibn Hibban). And (sometimes, when he wanted to pray voluntary prayer on his she-camel, he would face the Qiblah with it, say Takbeer, then pray wherever his mount directed him) (Ahmad and At-Tirmidhi, and he authenticated it). And (he used to bow and prostrate on his mount regarding it by gesturing with his head, making the prostration lower than the bowing) (Al-Bukhari and Ahmad). And (when he wanted to pray the obligatory prayer, he would dismount and face the Qiblah).

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Bukhari and Muslim) As for the prayer during intense fear, the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) legislated for his nation that they pray (walking on foot, standing on their feet, or riding; facing the Qiblah or not facing it). And the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (Al-Bayhaqi with a Sahih chain) (If they engage in close combat, then it is merely Takbeer [saying Allahu Akbar] and gesturing with the head) (Tirmidhi and Al-Hakim). And the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to say: (What is between the East and the West is a Qiblah) (Daraqutni, Al-Hakim, and Al-Bayhaqi). And Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) said: (We were with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) on a march or a military expedition, and we were covered by clouds, so we strove to determine the direction and differed regarding the Qiblah. So every man among us prayed separately, and one of us would mark a line in front of him so we would know our places. When morning came, we looked at it and found we had prayed towards other than the Qiblah. We mentioned that to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) [and he did not command us to repeat it] and said: (Your prayer has sufficed) (Bukhari, Muslim, and Ahmed). And the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to pray towards Bayt al-Maqdis (Jerusalem) - [with the Kaaba in front of him] - before this verse was revealed: {We have certainly seen the turning of your face, [O Muhammad], toward the heaven, and We will surely turn you to a qiblah with which you will be pleased. So turn your face toward al-Masjid al-Haram} [Surah Al-Baqarah (2:144)]. When it was revealed, he faced the Kaaba. While the people were at Quba' in the Morning Prayer, a comer came to them and said: Indeed, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) has had Quran revealed to him tonight...

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: ...and has been commanded to face the Kaaba, [unquestionably], so face it. Their faces were towards Sham (Syria/Jerusalem), so they turned around [and their Imam turned until he faced the Qiblah with them]). Standing (Qiyam): The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to stand in it (the prayer) upright in obligatory and voluntary prayers, in obedience to His saying, the Exalted: {And stand before Allah, devoutly obedient} [Al-Baqarah: 238]. As for in travel, he used to pray the voluntary prayer (Nafilah) on his mount. And he legislated for his nation that they pray during intense fear on their feet or riding, as mentioned previously, and that is His saying, the Exalted: {Maintain with care the [obligatory] prayers and [in particular] the middle prayer and stand before Allah, devoutly obedient. And if you fear [an enemy], then [pray] on foot or riding. But when you are secure, then remember Allah [in prayer], as He has taught you that which you did not [previously] know} [Al-Baqarah: 238-239] (Tirmidhi, who authenticated it, and Ahmed). And (the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) prayed sitting during his fatal illness) (Bukhari and Muslim). He also prayed like that another time before this when (he complained [of illness] and the people prayed behind him standing, so he gestured to them to sit, so they sat. When he finished, he said: (You were just about to do the deed of the Persians and Romans; they stand over their kings while they [the kings] are...

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: ...seated. So do not do that. The Imam is only appointed to be followed; so if he bows, bow, and if he rises, rise, and if he prays sitting, then pray sitting [all together]) Prayer of the Sick Person Sitting.

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: And Imran bin Husain (may Allah be pleased with him) said: (I had hemorrhoids, so I asked the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and he said: (Bukhari, Abu Dawood, and Ahmed) (Pray standing; if you cannot, then sitting; if you cannot, then on a side). He also said: (I asked him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) about the prayer of a man while he is sitting, so he said: (Bukhari, Abu Dawood, and Ahmed) (Whoever prays standing, it is best; and whoever prays sitting, he has half the reward of the one standing; and whoever prays sleeping (and in a narration: lying down), he has half the reward of the one sitting). The meaning here is the sick person, for Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) said: (Ahmed and Ibn Majah with a Sahih chain) (The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) came out to some people while they were praying sitting due to illness, so he said: (Indeed, the prayer of the one sitting is half of the prayer of the one standing). And (the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) visited a sick person and saw him praying on a pillow, so he took it and threw it aside. So [the man] took...

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: ...a stick to pray upon it, so he took it and threw it aside and said: (Tabarani, Al-Bazzar, Ibn Al-Sammak, and Al-Bayhaqi, and its chain is Sahih) (Pray on the ground if you are able, and if not, then gesture [with the head], and make your prostration lower than your bowing). Prayer in a Ship.

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: And the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was asked about prayer in a ship, so he said: (Al-Bazzar and Daraqutni, and Al-Hakim authenticated it) (Pray in it standing unless you fear drowning) (Abu Dawood and Al-Hakim; he and Al-Dhahabi authenticated it). And when the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) grew old and aged, he took a support (pillar) in his prayer place to lean on. Standing and Sitting in the Night Prayer (Muslim and Abu Dawood). And (the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to pray for a long time at night standing and for a long time sitting. If he recited standing, he would bow standing, and if he recited sitting, he would bow sitting) (Bukhari and Muslim). And (sometimes he would pray sitting, so he would recite while sitting, and when there remained from his recitation...

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: ...an amount of thirty or forty verses, he would stand up and recite them while standing, then bow and prostrate, then he would do the same in the second Rak'ah) (Muslim and Ahmed). Indeed, he (prayed the Subha [voluntary prayer] sitting at the end of his life when he grew old, and that was a year before his death) (Nasa'i, Ibn Khuzaymah, and Al-Hakim who authenticated it and Al-Dhahabi agreed). And (he used to sit cross-legged). Prayer in Sandals and the Command to do so.

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Abu Dawood and Ibn Majah) And (he used to stand barefoot sometimes and wearing sandals sometimes). And he permitted that for his nation, saying: (Abu Dawood and Al-Bazzar, and Al-Hakim authenticated it and Al-Dhahabi agreed) (When one of you prays, let him wear his sandals or take them off between his feet, and let him not harm others with them). And he emphasized praying in them sometimes to them, saying: (Abu Dawood and Al-Bazzar, and Al-Hakim authenticated it and Al-Dhahabi agreed) (Differ from the Jews, for they do not pray in their sandals nor their leather socks). And perhaps he would remove them from his feet while in prayer and then continue his prayer, as Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri said:

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Abu Dawood and Ibn Khuzaymah) (The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) prayed with us one day, and while he was in part of his prayer, he took off his sandals and placed them to his left. When the people saw that, they took off their sandals. When he finished his prayer, he said: (What is the matter with you that you cast off your sandals?) They said: We saw you cast off your sandals so we cast off our sandals. He said: (Indeed Gabriel came to me and informed me that there was filth - or he said: harm (and in a narration: impurity) on them, so I cast them off. So when one of you comes to the mosque, let him look at his sandals; if he sees filth - or he said: - harm (and in the other narration: impurity) on them, let him wipe them and pray in them) (Abu Dawood, Nasa'i, and Ibn Khuzaymah). And (when he removed them, he placed them to his left). And he used to say: (Abu Dawood and Ibn Khuzaymah) (If one of you prays, let him not place his sandals to his right nor to his left so they would be on the right of someone else, unless there is no one on his left, but let him place them between his feet). Prayer on the Minbar (Pulpit).

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Bukhari and Muslim) And (the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) prayed once - on the Minbar (and in a narration: which had three steps). So he [stood upon it and said Takbeer, and the people behind him said Takbeer while he was on the Minbar]. [Then he bowed while upon it], then he raised [his head] and descended backwards until he prostrated at the base of the Minbar, then he returned...

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: ...and did as he did in the first Rak'ah] until he finished the end of his prayer. Then he turned to the people and said: (O people, I only did this so you would follow me and learn my prayer). The Sutrah (Barrier) and its Obligation.

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Bukhari and Ahmed) And (the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to stand close to the Sutrah, so there was between him and the wall [a distance of] three cubits) (Bukhari and Muslim). And (between the place of his prostration and the wall was [space for] a sheep to pass) (Ibn Khuzaymah). And he used to say: (Do not pray except towards a Sutrah, and do not let anyone pass in front of you. If he refuses, then fight him, for he has a companion [qareen/devil] with him) (Abu Dawood and Al-Bazzar, and Al-Hakim authenticated it and Al-Dhahabi agreed). And he said: (When one of you prays towards a Sutrah, let him get close to it so Satan does not sever his prayer). And (he used to - sometimes - seek to pray at the pillar which was in his mosque).

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Bukhari and Muslim) And (when he prayed [in an open space where there was nothing to screen him], he would plant a short spear in front of him and pray towards it, with the people behind him). And sometimes (he would turn his mount sideways and pray towards it); this is different from praying in the camel pens, for he (forbade that). And sometimes (he would take the saddle, straighten it, and pray towards the back of it) (Muslim and Abu Dawood). And he used to say: (If one of you places in front of him something like the back of a saddle, let him pray and not mind whoever passes beyond that) (Nasa'i and Ahmed with a Sahih chain). And (he prayed - once - towards a tree) (Bukhari, Muslim, and Abu Ya'la). And (he used to - sometimes - pray towards the bed while Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) was lying on it [under her velvet cover]) (Ibn Khuzaymah in his Sahih and At-Tabarani). And the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) would not let anything pass between him and the Sutrah; indeed (he was praying when a sheep came running in front of him, so he raced it until he pressed his belly against the wall [and it passed behind him]).

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Ahmed, Daraqutni, and Tabarani with a Sahih chain) And (he prayed an obligatory prayer and clenched his hand. When he finished praying, they said: O Messenger of Allah, has something new happened in the prayer? He said: (No, except that the Devil wanted to pass in front of me, so I strangled him until I felt the coldness of his tongue on my hand. By Allah, were it not for what my brother Solomon preceded me in, he would have been bound to one of the pillars of the mosque so the children of the people of Medina could circle around him. [So whoever can prevent anyone from coming between him and the Qiblah, let him do so]). And he used to say: (Bukhari and Muslim) (If one of you prays towards something that screens him from the people, and someone wants to pass in front of him, let him push him away at the chest [and repel him as much as he can] (and in a narration: let him stop him twice). If he refuses, let him fight him, for he is only a devil) (Bukhari and Muslim). And he used to say: (If the one passing in front of the praying person knew what was upon him [of sin], it would be better for him to stand for forty rather than to pass in front of him).

text: (Muslim, Abu Dawood, and Ibn Khuzaymah) And he used to say: (The prayer of a man is cut - if there is not in front of him something like the back of a saddle - by: a woman [who has reached menstruation age], a donkey, and a black dog). Abu Dharr said: I said: O Messenger of Allah, what is the difference between the black dog and the red one? He said: (The black dog is a devil). Prayer Towards a Grave.

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: And he used to forbid praying towards a grave, saying: (Muslim, Abu Dawood, and Ibn Khuzaymah) (Do not pray towards graves and do not sit upon them). The Intention (Niyyah).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Bukhari, Muslim, and others) And the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to say: (Actions are but by intentions, and every person shall have only what he intended).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Muslim and Ibn Majah) Then the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to begin the prayer by saying: (Allahu Akbar) [Allah is the Greatest]. And he commanded (the one who prayed badly) to do so, as previously mentioned, and said to him: (Tabarani with a Sahih chain) (Indeed, the prayer of none of the people is complete until he performs ablution and places the ablution [water] in its places, then says: Allahu Akbar) (Abu Dawood and Tirmidhi, and Al-Hakim authenticated it and Al-Dhahabi agreed). And he used to say: (The key to prayer is purification, its prohibition [commencement that forbids other actions] is the Takbeer, and its permission [conclusion that allows other actions] is the Tasleem) (Ahmed and Al-Hakim, who authenticated it and Al-Dhahabi agreed). And (he used to raise his voice with the Takbeer until those behind him could hear). (Muslim and Nasa'i). And (when he was ill, Abu Bakr used to raise his voice to convey the Takbeer of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to the people (Ahmed and Al-Bayhaqi with a Sahih chain). And he used to say: (When the Imam says Allahu Akbar, then say Allahu Akbar).

(Abu Dawood and Ibn Khuzaymah) He used to raise them with fingers extended [neither spreading them out nor clasping them together]) (Bukhari and Abu Dawood). And (he used to place them level with his shoulders, and perhaps he would raise them until they were level with the [tops of] his ears). Placing the Right Hand over the Left and the Command to do so.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh

(Ibn Hibban and Al-Diya' with a Sahih chain) (And he used to say: (We, the assembly of Prophets, have been commanded to hasten our breaking of the fast, delay our Suhoor, and to place our right hands over our left hands in prayer). (Ahmed and Abu Dawood with a Sahih chain) (He passed by a man who was praying and had placed his left hand over the right, so he pulled it away and placed the right over the left).

(And he commanded his companions to do that). (Nasa'i and Daraqutni with a Sahih chain). And (he used to - sometimes - grasp the left hand with the right). (Abu Dawood and Ibn Khuzaymah in his Sahih). And (he used to place them on the chest). (Bukhari and Muslim). And (he used to forbid *Ikhtisar* in prayer), which is placing the hands on the hips...

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: ...which he used to forbid. (Abu Dawood and Nasa'i). Looking at the Place of Prostration and Humility (Khushu').

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Al-Bayhaqi and Al-Hakim) And (the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), when he prayed, would lower his head and cast his gaze towards the ground). (Al-Bayhaqi and Al-Hakim, who authenticated it). And (when he entered the Kaaba, his gaze did not leave the place of his prostration until he came out of it). (Abu Dawood and Ahmed with a Sahih chain). And the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (It is not fitting that there be anything in the House [Kaaba] that distracts the person praying). (Bukhari and Abu Dawood). And (he used to forbid raising one's gaze to the sky). And he emphasized the prohibition until he said: (Bukhari and Muslim) (People must stop raising their gazes to the sky in prayer, or else they [their sights] will not return to them (and in a narration: or their sights will be snatched away). (Tirmidhi and Al-Hakim, who authenticated it). And in another hadith: (So when you pray, do not look around, for indeed Allah sets His Face to the face of His servant in his prayer as long as he does not look around). And he also said regarding looking around: (Bukhari and Abu Dawood) (It is a snatching that the Devil snatches from the prayer of the servant).

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Narrated by Abu Dawood and others, and authenticated by Ibn Khuzaymah and Ibn Hibban). And the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (Allah continues to turn towards the servant in his prayer as long as he does not look around; if he turns his face, He turns away from him). (Ahmed and Abu Ya'la). And (he forbade three things: pecking like a rooster [rushing prostration], squatting like a dog [Iq'a], and looking around like a fox). (Ibn Majah and Ahmed, and authenticated by Al-Haythami the jurist). And the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to say: (Pray the prayer of a farewell [man], as if you see Him, for if you do not see Him, surely He sees you). (Muslim). And he said: (There is no man who, when the time for a prescribed prayer comes, performs its ablution, humility, and bowing well, except that it will be an expiation for the sins that preceded it, as long as he does not commit a major sin, and that is for all time). (Bukhari, Muslim, and Malik). And (the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) prayed in a Khamisah [garment] that had markings. He looked at its markings once. When he finished, he said: (Take this Khamisah of mine to Abu Jahm and bring me the Anbijaniyah [plain rough garment] of Abu Jahm, for it distracted me just now from my prayer (and in a narration: for I looked at its marking in the prayer and it almost put me to trial).

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: And (Aisha had a garment with pictures on it screened towards a niche/shelf, and the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to pray towards it, so he said: (Bukhari and Muslim) (Remove it from me, [for its pictures continue to appear to me in my prayer]). (Bukhari and Muslim). And he used to say: (There is no prayer in the presence of food nor while he is suppressing the two filths [urging to relieve oneself]). Supplications of Commencement (Istiftah).

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Abu Dawood, and Al-Hakim authenticated it and Al-Dhahabi agreed). Then the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to commence the recitation with many varied supplications in which he praised Allah the Exalted, glorified Him, and extolled Him. He commanded this to (the one who prayed badly), saying to him: (The prayer of no one among the people is complete until he says Takbeer, praises Allah Almighty and Glorious, extols Him, and recites what is easy from the Quran...) He used to recite sometimes with this and sometimes with that. He used to say: 1 - (Bukhari and Muslim) (Allahumma ba'id bayni wa bayna khatayaya kama ba'adta bayna al-mashriqi wal-maghrib. Allahumma naqqini min khatayaya kama yunaqqa ath-thawbu al-abyadu min ad-danas. Allahumma ighsilni min khatayaya bil-ma'i wath-thalji wal-barad) [O Allah, distance me from my sins as You have distanced the East from the West. O Allah, purify me from my sins as a white garment is purified from dirt. O Allah, wash me from my sins with water, snow, and hail]. He used to say this in the obligatory prayer.

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 2 - (Muslim, Abu Awanah, and others) (Wajjahtu wajhiya lilladhi fatara as-samawati wal-arda hanifan [musliman] wa ma ana min al-mushrikeen. Inna salati wa nusuki wa mahyaya wa mamati lillahi rabbil-alameen, la shareeka lahu wa bidhalika umirtu wa ana awwalul-muslimeen. Allahumma anta al-maliku la ilaha illa ant [subhanaka wa bihamdik] anta rabbi wa ana 'abduk, zalamtu nafsi wa'taraftu bidhanbi faghfir li dhanbi jamee'an, innahu la yaghfir udh-dhunooba illa ant. Wahdini li-ahsanil-akhlaq la yahdee li-ahsaniha illa ant, wasrif 'anni sayyi'aha la yasrifu 'anni sayyi'aha illa ant. Labbayka wa sa'dayka wal-khayru kulluhu fee yadayk wash-sharru laysa ilayk [wal-mahdiyu man hadayt] ana bika wa ilayk [la manja wa la malja'a minka illa ilayk] tabarakta wa ta'alayt astaghfiruka wa atoobu ilayk). [I have turned my face towards the One Who originated the heavens and the earth, inclining to truth [as a Muslim], and I am not of the polytheists. Indeed, my prayer, my sacrifice, my living, and my dying are for Allah, Lord of the worlds. No partner has He. And this I have been commanded, and I am the first of the Muslims. O Allah, You are the King, there is no deity except You. [Glory be to You and by Your praise], You are my Lord and I am Your servant. I have wronged myself and admitted my sin, so forgive me all my sins. Indeed, no one forgives sins except You. Guide me to the best of morals; no one guides to the best of them except You. And turn away from me the evil of them; no one turns away from me the evil of them except You. I am here and happy to serve You. All good is in Your hands, and evil is not attributed to You. [The guided one is he whom You guide]. I exist by You and return to You. [There is no escape and no refuge from You except to You]. Blessed are You and Exalted. I seek Your forgiveness and repent to You].

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: He used to say it in obligatory and voluntary prayers. 3 - (Nasa'i with a Sahih chain) Similar to it, without saying: (You are my Lord and I am Your servant) etc. - and adding: (O Allah, You are the King, there is no deity except You, Glory be to You and by Your praise). 4 - (Nasa'i and Daraqutni with a Sahih chain) Similar to it as well, up to the phrase: (and I am the first of the Muslims), and adding: (O Allah, guide me to the best of morals and the best of deeds - no one guides to the best of them except You. And protect me from evil morals and deeds - no one protects from the evil of them except You). 5 - (Abu Dawood, and Al-Hakim authenticated it and Al-Dhahabi agreed) (Subhanaka Allahumma wa bihamdika wa tabaraka ismuka wa ta'ala jadduka wa la ilaha ghayruk) [Glory be to You, O Allah, and by Your praise, and blessed is Your Name, and exalted is Your Majesty, and there is no deity other than You]. And the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (Ibn Mandah with a Sahih chain, and Nasa'i as Mawquf and Marfu') (Indeed, the most beloved speech to Allah is that the servant says: Subhanaka Allahumma...) 6 - (Abu Dawood and At-Tahawi with a Hasan chain) (Similar to it, and he adds in the night prayer: (La ilaha illa Allah [There is no deity but Allah] (three times), Allahu Akbar Kabira [Allah is Most Great] (three times).

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 7 - (Muslim and Abu Awanah) (Allahu Akbar Kabira, wal-hamdu lillahi katheera, wa subhan Allahi bukratan wa aseela) [Allah is Most Great, and much praise be to Allah, and glory be to Allah morning and evening]. A man from the Companions opened with it, so the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (I was amazed by it; the gates of heaven were opened for it). 8 - (Muslim and Abu Awanah) (Al-hamdu lillahi hamdan katheeran tayyiban mubarakan feeh) [Praise be to Allah, much, good and blessed praise]. Another man opened with it, so the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (I saw twelve angels racing for it, which of them would raise it). 9 - (Bukhari and Muslim) (Allahumma lakal-hamdu anta noorus-samawati wal-ard wa man feehinna, wa lakal-hamdu anta qayyimus-samawati wal-ard wa man feehinna [wa lakal-hamdu anta malikus-samawati wal-ard wa man feehinna] wa lakal-hamdu antal-haqq, wa wa'dukal-haqq, wa qawlukal-haqq, wa liqa'uka haqq, wal-jannatu haqq, wan-naru haqq, was-sa'atu haqq, wan-nabiyyoona haqq, wa Muhammadun haqq. Allahumma laka aslamtu, wa 'alayka tawakkaltu, wa bika amantu, wa ilayka anabtu, wa bika khasamtu, wa ilayka hakamtu [anta rabbuna wa ilaykal-maseer, faghfir li ma qaddamtu wa ma akhartu, wa ma asrartu wa ma a'lantu] [wa ma anta a'lamu bihi minnee] antal-muqaddimu wa antal-mu'akhkhiru [anta ilahee] la ilaha illa ant [wa la hawla wa la quwwata illa bik]). [O Allah, to You belongs praise. You are the Light of the heavens and the earth and whoever is in them. And to You belongs praise. You are the Sustainer of the heavens and the earth and whoever is in them. [And to You belongs praise. You are the King of the heavens and the earth and whoever is in them]. And to You belongs praise. You are the Truth, Your promise is true, Your speech is true, the meeting with You is true, Paradise is true, the Fire is true, the Hour is true, the Prophets are true, and Muhammad is true. O Allah, to You I have submitted, upon You I have relied, in You I have believed, to You I have turned, with You I have disputed, and to You I have referred for judgment. [You are our Lord and to You is the destination. So forgive me what I have put forth and what I have delayed, what I have concealed and what I have declared] [and what You know better about than me]. You are the One who puts forward and You are the One who delays. [You are my God]. There is no deity except You. [And there is no power and no strength except with You]].

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: And the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to say it in the night prayer, like the following types: 10 - (Muslim and Abu Awanah) (Allahumma rabba Jibra'eela wa Mika'eela wa Israfeela fatiras-samawati wal-ard 'alimal-ghaybi wash-shahadah, anta tahkumu bayna 'ibadika feema kanoo feehi yakhtalifoon. Ihdinee lima ikhtulifa feehi minal-haqqi bi-idhnika, innaka tahdee man tasha'u ila siratim-mustaqeem) [O Allah, Lord of Gabriel, Michael, and Israfil, Originator of the heavens and the earth, Knower of the unseen and the witnessed, You judge between Your servants concerning that wherein they differ. Guide me to the truth regarding that wherein they differed, by Your permission. Indeed, You guide whom You will to a straight path]. 11 - (Ahmed and Ibn Abi Shaybah) He used to say Takbeer ten times, Tahmeed (Praise) ten times, Tasbeeh (Glory) ten times, Tahleel (La ilaha illa Allah) ten times, and Istighfar (seek forgiveness) ten times, and say: (Allahumma aghfir li wahdini warzuqni [wa 'afini]) [O Allah, forgive me, guide me, provide for me [and grant me wellbeing]] ten times, and say: (Allahumma innee a'udhu bika minad-deeqi yawmal-hisab) [O Allah, I seek refuge in You from distress on the Day of Account] ten times. 12 - (At-Tayalisi and Abu Dawood with a Sahih chain) (Allahu Akbar [three times] Dhul-malakooti wal-jabarooti wal-kibriya'i wal-'azamah) [Allah is the Greatest (3 times), Possessor of Sovereignty, Power, Grandeur, and Greatness]. The Recitation.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Then the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to seek refuge in Allah the Exalted, saying: (Abu Dawood, Ibn Majah, and Daraqutni) (A'udhu billahi minash-shaytanir-rajeem min hamzihi wa nafkhihi wa nafthih) [I seek refuge in Allah from the accursed Satan, from his madness, his arrogance, and his poetry].

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Abu Dawood and Tirmidhi with a Hasan chain) And sometimes he would add to it, saying: (A'udhu billahis-samee'il-'aleem minash-shaytan...) [I seek refuge in Allah, the All-Hearing, the All-Knowing, from Satan...]. (Bukhari and Muslim) Then he would read: (Bismillahi ar-Rahman ar-Raheem) [In the Name of Allah, the Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful], and he would not recite it loudly. Reading Verse by Verse.

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Abu Dawood and Al-Sahmi) (Then he would read Al-Fatihah and break it [pause] verse by verse: Bismillahi ar-Rahman ar-Raheem [then he pauses, then says:] Al-hamdu lillahi rabbil-'alameen [then he pauses, then says:] Ar-Rahman ar-Raheem [then he pauses, then says:] Maliki yawmid-deen. And so on until the end of the Surah. And likewise was all his recitation; he would stop at the heads [ends] of the verses and not connect them to what followed. (Tamam Al-Ra'izi and Ibn Abi Dawood in 'Al-Masahif'). And sometimes he would read it: Maliki yawmid-deen [King of the Day of Judgment, as opposed to Malik/Owner].

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: And he used to emphasize the importance of this Surah, so he would say: (Bukhari and Muslim) (There is no prayer for the one who does not read the Opening of the Book [Al-Fatihah] [and more]). (Daraqutni, who authenticated it, and Ibn Hibban). And in a wording: (A prayer in which a man does not read the Opening of the Book does not suffice). And sometimes he said: (Muslim and Abu Awanah) (Whoever prays a prayer in which he does not read the Opening of the Book, it is deficient [khidaj], it is deficient, it is deficient, incomplete). And he said: (Muslim, Abu Awanah, and Malik) (Allah the Blessed and Exalted said: I have divided the prayer - meaning Al-Fatihah - between Me and My servant into two halves: half of it is for Me and half of it is for My servant, and My servant shall have what he asked for). And the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (Read: The servant says: Al-hamdu lillahi rabbil-'alameen. Allah the Exalted says: My servant has praised Me. And the servant says: Ar-Rahman ar-Raheem. Allah says: My servant has extolled Me. And the servant says: Maliki yawmid-deen. Allah the Exalted says: My servant has glorified Me. The servant says: Iyyaka na'budu wa iyyaka nasta'een. [He said]: This is between Me and My servant, and My servant shall have what he asked for. The servant says: Ihdinas-siratal-mustaqeem, siratal-ladheena an'amta 'alayhim ghayril-maghdoobi 'alayhim wa lad-dalleen. [He said]: These are for My servant, and My servant shall have what he asked for).

text: (Bukhari) And he had permitted those following the Imam to read it behind the Imam in the loud prayer, where he was (in the Fajr prayer and recited, but the recitation became difficult for him. When he finished, he said: (Perhaps you recite behind your Imam?) We said: Yes, indeed, O Messenger of Allah. He said:

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It

text: (Do not do so except [that one of you reads] the Opening of the Book, for there is no prayer for the one who does not read it). (Malik, Al-Humaydi, and Bukhari in his 'Juz'). Then he forbade them from reciting at all in the loud prayer. That was when (he finished a prayer in which he recited loudly (and in a narration: it was the Morning Prayer) and said: (Did any of you recite with me just now?) A man said: Yes, I did, O Messenger of Allah. He said: Indeed I say: (Why am I being contended with [in Quran]?) [Abu Hurairah said:] So the people stopped reciting with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in the prayers where the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) recited loudly - when they heard that from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) [and they recited within themselves silently in the prayers where the Imam does not recite loudly]). And he made listening silently to the Imam's recitation part of the completeness of following him, saying: (Muslim and Abu Awanah) (The Imam is only appointed to be followed; so if he says Takbeer, say Takbeer, and if he recites, then listen silently).

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Ibn Majah with a Sahih chain) As for the silent prayer, he approved of them reciting in it. Jabir said: (We used to recite in Zuhr and Asr behind the Imam in the first two Rak'ahs the Opening of the Book and a Surah, and in the last two the Opening of the Book). (Muslim and Abu Awanah). He only disapproved of disturbing him with it. That was when (he prayed Zuhr with his companions and said: (Which of you recited 'Sabbihisma rabbikal-a'la' [Glorify the Name of your Lord, the Most High]?) A man said: Me, [and I only intended good by it]. He said: (I knew that a man was contending with me in it). (Bukhari). And in another hadith: (They were reciting behind the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) [and raising their voices with it], so he said: (You have mixed up the Quran for me). (Bukhari in 'Af'al Al-Ibad' with a Sahih chain). And he said: (Indeed the one praying is privately conversing with his Lord, so let him look at how he converses with Him, and let not some of you raise your voices over others with the Quran).

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Bukhari in 'Juz Al-Qira'ah'). Then (the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), when he finished reciting Al-Fatihah, would say: (Ameen), saying it loudly and prolonging his voice with it). (Bukhari and Muslim). And he used to command the followers to say Ameen immediately after the Imam's Ameen, saying: (When the Imam says: 'Ghayril-maghdoobi 'alayhim wa lad-dalleen', then say: Ameen [for the angels say: Ameen, and the Imam says: Ameen] (and in a wording: When the Imam says Ameen, then say Ameen). For whoever's Ameen coincides with the Ameen of the angels (and in another wording: If one of you says in the prayer: Ameen, and the angels in the heaven say: Ameen, and one of them coincides with the other), his previous sins will be forgiven).

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Then the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to recite another Surah after Al-Fatihah. He would make it long sometimes and short sometimes due to reasons of travel, coughing, illness, or the crying of a child, as Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) said: (The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) shortened the prayer one day in Fajr) (and in another hadith: He prayed Morning Prayer and recited the two shortest Surahs in the Quran). It was said: O Messenger of Allah, why did you shorten it? He said: (Ahmed with a Sahih chain) (I heard the crying of a child, and I thought his mother was praying with us, so I wanted to free his mother for him).

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Bukhari and Muslim). And he used to say: (Indeed I enter the prayer intending to prolong it, then I hear the crying of a child, so I shorten my prayer because of what I know of his mother's intense distress at his crying). And he used to start from the beginning of the Surah and complete it in most of his states (Ibn Abi Shaybah and Ahmed). And he said: (Give every Surah its share of bowing and prostration). (Ibn Nasr and At-Tahawi with a Sahih chain) (And in a wording: (For every Surah a Rak'ah). (Ahmed and Abu Ya'la). And sometimes he would divide it into two Rak'ahs, and sometimes he would repeat the whole thing in the second Rak'ah. And sometimes he would combine two or more Surahs in one Rak'ah.

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It

text: (Bukhari and Muslim) And (he used to combine the similar Surahs [Naza'ir] from the Mufassal section, so he would read Surah Ar-Rahman (55) and An-Najm (53), and Iqtarabat [Al-Qamar] (54) and Al-Haqqah (69) in one Rak'ah, and At-Tur (52) and...

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: ...Adh-Dhariyat (51) in one Rak'ah, and Idha Waqa'at [Al-Waqi'ah] (56) and Nun [Al-Qalam] (68) in one Rak'ah, and Sa'ala Sa'il [Al-Ma'arij] (70) and An-Nazi'at (79) in one Rak'ah, and Waylul-lil-Mutaffifeen (83) and 'Abasa (80) in one Rak'ah, and Al-Muddaththir (74) and Al-Muzzammil (73) in one Rak'ah, and Hal Ata [Al-Insan] (76) and La Uqsimu bi-yawmil-Qiyamah (75) in one Rak'ah, and 'Amma Yatasa'aloon [An-Naba'] (78) and Al-Mursalat (77) in one Rak'ah, and Ad-Dukhan (44) and Idha ash-Shamsu Kuwwirat [At-Takwir] (81) in one Rak'ah) (Muslim and At-Tahawi). And sometimes he would combine Surahs from the Seven Long Ones like Al-Baqarah, An-Nisa, and Ali Imran in one Rak'ah of the night prayer as will come later. And he used to say: (The best prayer is the one with long standing [Qiyam]). (Abu Dawood and Al-Bayhaqi with a Sahih chain). (And (when he read: 'A-laysa dhalika bi-qadirin 'ala an yuhyi al-mawta' [Is not that One able to give life to the dead?], he would say: 'Subhanaka fa-bala' [Glory be to You, yes indeed]. And when he read 'Sabbihisma rabbikal-a'la' [Glorify the Name of your Lord, the Most High], he would say: (Subhana rabbiyal-a'la) [Glory be to my Lord, the Most High].

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Ibn Khuzaymah in his Sahih and Al-Bayhaqi with a good chain). And (Mu'adh used to pray Isha [the last one] with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), then return and pray with his companions. He returned one night and prayed with them, and a young man from his people [from Banu Salimah named Sulaym] prayed. When it became too long for the youth, [he turned away and] prayed [in a corner of the mosque], then went out, took the rein of his camel, and left. When Mu'adh finished, that was mentioned to him, so he said: Indeed, he has hypocrisy in him; I will surely inform the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) of what he did. And the youth said: And I will surely inform the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) of what he did. So they went to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in the morning, and Mu'adh informed him of what the youth did. The youth said: O Messenger of Allah, he stays long with you then returns and prolongs it for us. So the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (Are you a source of trial, O Mu'adh?) And he said to the youth: (What do you do, O nephew, when you pray?). He said: I read the Opening of the Book, and I ask Allah for Paradise and seek refuge in Him from the Fire, and I do not know your humming nor the humming of Mu'adh. So the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (It is around these two that I and Mu'adh hum [revolve]). He said: The youth said: But Mu'adh will know when the people arrive and have been informed that the enemy has come. He said: So they arrived and the youth was martyred. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said to Mu'adh after that: (What did my adversary and your adversary do?). He said: O Messenger of Allah, Allah was truthful and I lied; he was martyred).

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: And the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to recite loudly in the Morning Prayer (Subh) and in the first two Rak'ahs of Maghrib and Isha, and silently in Zuhr, Asr, the third of Maghrib, and the last two of Isha. (Bukhari and Abu Dawood). And they knew his recitation in the silent prayers by the movement of his beard (Bukhari and Muslim) and by his making them hear a verse sometimes. (Bukhari and Abu Dawood). And he also used to recite loudly in the Friday prayer, the two Eids, the prayer for rain (Istisqa) (Bukhari and Muslim), and the Eclipse prayer.

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Bukhari and Muslim) As for the night prayer, he would sometimes recite silently and sometimes loudly. (Abu Dawood and Tirmidhi). And (when he recited while inside the house, those in the courtyard could hear his recitation). (Nasa'i and Tirmidhi). And (perhaps he would raise his voice more than that until those who were in the trellis [outside] could hear him). (Abu Dawood and Al-Hakim, who authenticated it and Al-Dhahabi agreed). And he commanded Abu Bakr and Umar (may Allah be pleased with them) regarding that. That was when (he went out one night and found Abu Bakr (may Allah be pleased with him) praying and lowering his voice, and he passed by Umar bin Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him) while he was praying and raising his voice. When they gathered with the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), he said: (O Abu Bakr, I passed by you and you were praying lowering your voice). He said: I made the One I was conversing with hear, O Messenger of Allah. And he said to Umar: (I passed by you and you were praying raising your voice). He said: O Messenger of Allah, I wake the sleeping and drive away the Devil. So the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (O Abu Bakr, raise your voice a little). And he said to Umar: (Lower your voice a little).

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: As for what the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to recite in the prayers from Surahs and verses, that varied according to the five prayers and others. Here is the detail of that, beginning with the first of the five prayers: 1 - The Fajr (Dawn) Prayer: (Nasa'i and Ahmed with a Sahih chain) The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to read the long Mufassal Surahs in it. (He would - sometimes - read: Al-Waqi'ah (56) and similar Surahs in the two Rak'ahs). (Bukhari and Muslim). And he read from Surah At-Tur (52), and that was in the Farewell Pilgrimage. (Muslim and Tirmidhi). (And (he would - sometimes - read: Qaf wal-Quranil-Majeed (50) and similar ones in the [first Rak'ah]). (Muslim and Abu Dawood). And (he would - sometimes - read the short Mufassal Surahs like: Idha ash-Shamsu Kuwwirat (81).

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Abu Dawood and Al-Bayhaqi with a Sahih chain). And (he read once: Idha Zulzilat (99) in both Rak'ahs, to the point that the narrator said: I do not know if the Messenger of Allah forgot or read that intentionally). (Abu Dawood and Ibn Khuzaymah). And (he read - once - in travel: Qul A'udhu bi-rabbil-Falaq (113) and Qul A'udhu bi-rabbin-Nas (114). And he said to Uqbah bin Amir (may Allah be pleased with him): (Abu Dawood and Ahmed with a Sahih chain) (Read the Mu'awwidhatayn [the two seeking refuge] in your prayer, [for no seeker of refuge has sought refuge with anything like them]). (Bukhari and Muslim). And sometimes he would read more than that; (he would read sixty verses or more). One of the narrators said: I do not know if in one Rak'ah or in both. (Nasa'i, Ahmed, and Al-Bazzar with a good chain). And (he used to read Surah Ar-Rum (30) (Ahmed with a Sahih chain) and - sometimes - Surah Yasin (36). And once (he prayed Subh in Mecca and began Surah Al-Mu'minun (23)...

book_title: The Prophet's Prayer Described from the beginning to the end as though you see it
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Ahmad with a Sahih chain) As for his recitation in the two Rak'ahs of the Sunnah of Fajr, it was very light (Al-Bukhari and Muslim), so much so that Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) used to say: (Did he recite the Mother of the Book [Al-Fatiha] in them?) (Muslim, Ibn Khuzaymah, and Al-Hakim). And (he used to - sometimes - recite after Al-Fatiha in the first of them the verse (2:136): 'Say, [O believers], "We have believed in Allah and what has been revealed to us..."' to the end of the verse, and in the other (3:64): 'Say, "O People of the Scripture, come to a word that is equitable between us and you..."' to the end of it).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Muslim and Abu Dawood) And (perhaps he recited instead of it (3:52): 'But when Jesus felt [persistence in] disbelief from them...' to the end of the verse) (Muslim and Abu Dawood) (And sometimes he recited: 'Say, "O disbelievers"' (109:1-6) in the first, and 'Say, "He is Allah, One"' (112:1-4) in the other (Ibn Majah and Ibn Khuzaymah). And sometimes the addition would be: 8 - (Muslim and Abu Awanah) (Mil'as-samawati wa mil'al-ardi wa mil'a ma shi'ta min shay'in ba'd. Ahlat-thana'i wal-majd, ahaqqu ma qalal-'abd, wa kulluna laka 'abd. [Allahumma] la mani'a lima a'tayta [wa la mu'tiya lima mana'ta] wa la yanfa'u dhal-jaddi minkal-jadd). And sometimes he would say in the night prayer: 9 - (Abu Dawood and An-Nasa'i with a Sahih chain) (Li-Rabbiyal-Hamd Li-Rabbiyal-Hamd - To my Lord is praise, to my Lord is praise). He repeated that until his standing was similar to his bowing, which was close to his first standing [in which he recited Surah Al-Baqarah].

book_title: The Prophet's Prayer Described from the beginning to the end as though you see it
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Al-Bukhari and Muslim) And he (peace be upon him) used to make this standing close to his bowing as previously mentioned. Indeed (he used to stand sometimes until one would say: (He has forgotten [due to the length of his standing])). And he used to command tranquility in it, so he said to the (one who prayed badly): (Al-Bukhari and Muslim) (Then raise your head until you stand straight [and every bone takes its place]) (and in a narration: (And when you raise, straighten your spine and raise your head until the bones return to their joints)). And he mentioned to him: (That no prayer is complete for any person if he does not do that).

book_title: The Prophet's Prayer Described from the beginning to the end as though you see it
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Sahih) Then (he, peace be upon him, used to say Takbir and go down prostrating). And he commanded the (one who prayed badly) to do so, saying to him: (No prayer is complete for any person until... he says: Sami'a Allahu liman Hamidah until...

book_title: The Prophet's Prayer Described from the beginning to the end as though you see it
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Ibn Khuzaymah and Al-Daraqutni) And (he used to place his hands on the ground before his knees) (Abu Dawood). And he used to command that, saying: (When one of you prostrates, let him not kneel as the camel kneels, and let him place his hands before his knees).

book_title: The Prophet's Prayer Described from the beginning to the end as though you see it
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Ibn Khuzaymah, Ahmad, and Al-Sarraj, and Al-Hakim classified it as Sahih and Al-Dhahabi agreed). And he used to say: (Indeed, the hands prostrate as the face prostrates. So when one of you places his face [on the ground], let him place his hands, and when he raises it, let him raise them). (Al-Bayhaqi with a Sahih chain) And (he used to lean on his palms [and spread them]). And he would keep their fingers together. And he would point them towards the Qiblah (Abu Dawood and An-Nasa'i with a Sahih chain). And (he used to place them opposite his shoulders) Abu Dawood and At-Tirmidhi. And sometimes (opposite his ears) (Abu Dawood and At-Tirmidhi, and he and Ibn Al-Mulaqqin classified it as Sahih). And (he used to firmly place his nose and his forehead on the ground).

book_title: The Prophet's Prayer Described from the beginning to the end as though you see it
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Abu Dawood and Ahmad with a Sahih chain) And he said to the (one who prayed badly): (If you prostrate, then be firm in your prostration). (Ibn Khuzaymah with a good chain) And in a narration (When you prostrate, place your face and hands firmly until every bone of yours settles in its place). (Al-Daraqutni and At-Tabarani) And he used to say: (There is no prayer for the one whose nose does not touch the ground just as the forehead touches). (Sahih) And (he used to also firmly place his knees and the tips of his feet). And (he faced the Qiblah with [the balls of his feet and] the tips of their toes). And (he kept his heels together). And (he kept his feet upright). And (he commanded to do so). And he used to open their toes [towards Qiblah]. So these are seven members upon which he (peace be upon him) used to prostrate: The two palms, the two knees, the two feet, and the forehead and the nose.

book_title: The Prophet's Prayer Described from the beginning to the end as though you see it
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: And the Prophet (peace be upon him) made the last two members as one member in prostration, where (Al-Bukhari and Muslim) he said: (I have been commanded to prostrate (and in a narration: We have been commanded to prostrate) on seven bones: on the forehead - and he pointed with his hand to his nose - and the hands (and in a wording: the palms), and the knees, and the tips of the feet, and that we do not tuck up the clothes and the hair). (Muslim, Abu Awanah, and Ibn Hibban) And he used to say: (When the servant prostrates, seven limbs prostrate with him: his face, his palms, his knees, and his feet). (Muslim and Abu Awanah) And he said regarding a man who prayed with his hair tied in a braid at the back: (The likeness of this one is only like the likeness of the one who prays while his hands are tied). And he also said:

book_title: The Prophet's Prayer Described from the beginning to the end as though you see it
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Abu Dawood and At-Tirmidhi and he classified it as Hasan) (That is the seat of the devil). Meaning: the sitting place of the devil. Meaning the place where his knot is tied. (Sahih) And (he used to not spread his forearms on the ground). Rather (he used to raise them from the ground and keep them away from his sides until the whiteness of his armpits appeared from behind him). And (even if a young goat wanted to pass under his arms, it could pass). He used to exaggerate in that until some of his companions said: (Abu Dawood and Ibn Majah with a good chain) (We used to feel pity for the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) due to how much he kept his hands away from his sides when he prostrated). (Muslim and Abu Awanah) And he used to command that, saying: (When you prostrate, place your palms and raise your elbows). (Al-Bukhari and Muslim) And he said: (Be straight in prostration, and let none of you spread his forearms as a dog spreads (and in a wording: as the spreading of) a dog). (Ahmad and At-Tirmidhi and he classified it as Sahih) And in another wording and another Hadith: (And let none of you spread his forearms the spreading of a dog). (Ibn Khuzaymah, Al-Maqdisi, and Al-Hakim, who classified it as Sahih and Al-Dhahabi agreed). And he used to say: (Do not spread your forearms [the spreading of...

book_title: The Prophet's Prayer Described from the beginning to the end as though you see it
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: And he (peace be upon him) used to say in this pillar various types of remembrances (Adhkar) and supplications, sometimes this and sometimes that: 1 - (Ahmad, Abu Dawood, Ibn Majah, and Al-Daraqutni) (Subhana Rabbiyal-A'la - Glory be to my Lord the Most High (three times). And (he used to - sometimes - repeat it more than that). And once he exaggerated in repeating it in the night prayer until his prostration was close to his...

book_title: The Prophet's Prayer Described from the beginning to the end as though you see it
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: ...standing. And he had recited in it three of the long Surahs: Al-Baqarah, An-Nisa, and Al-Imran - interspersed with supplication and seeking forgiveness as previously mentioned in (Night Prayer). 2 - (Sahih) (Subhana Rabbiyal-A'la wa bihamdih - Glory be to my Lord the Most High and by His praise (three times)). 3 - (Muslim and Abu Awanah) (Subbuhun Quddusun Rabbul-Mala'ikati war-Ruh). 4 - (Al-Bukhari and Muslim) (Subhanaka Allahumma Rabbana wa bihamdika Allahumma ighfir li). He used to say it frequently in his bowing and prostration, interpreting the Quran. 5 - (Muslim and Abu Awanah) (Allahumma laka sajadtu wa bika amantu wa laka aslamtu [wa Anta Rabbi] sajada wajhi lilladhi khalaqahu wa sawwarahu [fa-ahsana suratahu] wa shaqqa sam'ahu wa basarahu [fa]tabaraka Allahu ahsanul-khaliqin). 6 - (Muslim and Abu Awanah) (Allahumma ighfir li dhanbi kullahu wa diqqahu wa jillahu wa awwalahu wa akhirahu wa 'alaniyatahu wa sirrah - O Allah, forgive me all my sin, the small and the great of it, the first and the last of it, the open and the secret of it). 7 - (Ibn Nasr, Al-Bazzar, and Al-Hakim, who classified it as Sahih but Al-Dhahabi rejected it, yet it has supporting evidences mentioned in the origin [Al-Asl]) (Sajada laka sawadi wa khayali wa amana bika fu'adi abu'u bi-ni'matika 'alayya hadhi - yadi wa ma janaytu 'ala nafsi - My person and my shadow have prostrated to You, and my heart has believed in You. I acknowledge Your favor upon me. This is my hand and what I have committed against myself). 8 - (Abu Dawood and An-Nasa'i with a Sahih chain) (Subhana Dhil-Jabarut wal-Malakut wal-Kibriya' wal-'Azamah). And this...
