publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: And the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to make his prostration close to his bowing in length, and perhaps he exaggerated in...

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: ...prolonging it for an incidental matter, as some of the Companions said: (The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) came out to us in one of the two evening prayers - [Zuhr or Asr] - while he was carrying Al-Hasan or Al-Hussein. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) came forward and placed him [at his right foot], then he said Takbeer for the prayer and prayed. He prostrated a prostration during his prayer which he prolonged. [The narrator] said: I raised my head [from among the people] and saw the boy on the back of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) while he was prostrating, so I returned to my prostration. When the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) finished the prayer, the people said: O Messenger of Allah, you prostrated a prostration during [this] prayer of yours which you prolonged until we thought that something had happened or that revelation was coming to you. He said: (Nasa'i, Ibn Asakir, and Al-Hakim who authenticated it and Al-Dhahabi agreed) (None of that happened, but my son rode me, and I disliked rushing him until he fulfilled his need). (Ibn Khuzaymah in his Sahih). And in another hadith: (The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was praying, and when he prostrated, Al-Hasan and Al-Hussein would jump onto his back. When [the people] tried to stop them, he gestured to them to leave them alone. When he finished the prayer, he placed them in his lap and said: (Whoever loves me, let him love these two).

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Ahmed with a Sahih chain) And the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to say: (There is no one from my nation except that I will recognize him on the Day of Resurrection). They said: And how will you recognize them, O Messenger of Allah, among the multitude of creations? He said: (Do you not see that if you entered a corral in which there were pure black horses, and among them was a horse with a white blaze and white limbs, would you not recognize it among them?) He said: Yes. He said: (Then indeed, my nation on that Day will have white faces from prostration and white limbs from ablution). (Bukhari and Muslim). And he said: (When Allah wills mercy for whom He wills among the people of the Fire, Allah commands the angels to bring out those who used to worship Allah. So they bring them out, recognizing them by the traces of prostration. And Allah has forbidden the Fire from consuming the trace of prostration. So they come out of the Fire; the Fire consumes all of the son of Adam except the trace of prostration).

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: And he used to prostrate on the earth (ground) often. (Muslim and Abu Awanah). And (his Companions used to pray with him in intense heat; if one of them could not place his forehead on the ground, he would spread his garment and prostrate on it). (Ahmed, Al-Siraj, and Al-Bayhaqi with a Sahih chain). And he used to say: (...And the earth was made for me and my nation as a place of prayer and purification; so wherever prayer overtakes a man from my nation, he has his place of prayer and his purification [with him]. [Those before me used to consider that significant; they only prayed in their churches and synagogues]). (Bukhari and Muslim). And perhaps he prostrated in mud and water; this happened to him on the morning of the twenty-first night of Ramadan when the sky rained and the roof of the mosque, which was made of palm branches, leaked. So the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) prostrated in the water and mud. Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri said: (So my eyes saw the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) with the traces of water and mud on his forehead and nose). (Bukhari and Muslim). And (he used to pray on the Khumrah [small mat]) sometimes, and (on the Hasir [reed mat]) sometimes. And (he prayed on it - once - and it had turned black from how long it had been worn).

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Then (the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to raise his head from prostration saying Takbeer). And he commanded (the one who prayed badly) to do so, saying: (Ahmed and Abu Dawood with a Sahih chain) (The prayer of none of the people is complete until... he prostrates until his joints settle, then he says: 'Allahu Akbar' and raises his head until he is sitting upright). And (he used to raise his hands with this Takbeer) sometimes. (Bukhari). Then (he would spread his left leg and sit on it [calmly]). (Ahmed and Abu Dawood with a good chain). And he commanded (the one who prayed badly) to do so, saying to him: (When you prostrate, be firm in your prostration, and when you rise, sit on your left thigh). (Bukhari and Al-Bayhaqi). And (he used to keep his right foot upright). (Nasa'i with a Sahih chain). And (he would face the Qiblah with its toes).

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Abu Dawood and Al-Bayhaqi with a Sahih chain). And (the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to settle until every bone returned to its place). (Abu Dawood and Al-Hakim who authenticated it and Al-Dhahabi agreed). He commanded (the one who prayed badly) to do so, and said to him: (The prayer of one of you is not complete until he does that). (Bukhari and Muslim). And (he used to prolong it until it was close [in length] to his prostration). And sometimes (he would stay...

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to say in this sitting: 1 - (Abu Dawood, Tirmidhi, and Ibn Majah; Al-Hakim authenticated it and Al-Dhahabi agreed) (Allahumma (and in a wording: Rabb) ighfir li warhamni [wajburni] [warfa'ni] wahdini - [wa 'afini] warzuqni) [O Allah (or Lord), forgive me, have mercy on me, [fix my condition], [raise my rank], guide me, [grant me wellbeing], and provide for me]. And sometimes he would say: 2 - (Ibn Majah with a good chain) (Rabbi ighfir li, ighfir li) [My Lord, forgive me, forgive me]. He would say these in the (Night Prayer). (Bukhari and Muslim). Then (he would say Takbeer and prostrate the second prostration). And he commanded (the one who prayed badly) to do so, saying to him after commanding him to settle between the two prostrations as previously mentioned:

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Abu Dawood; Al-Hakim authenticated it and Al-Dhahabi agreed. The addition is from Bukhari and Muslim) (Then say: 'Allahu Akbar' then prostrate until your joints settle [then do that in all your prayer]). (Abu Awanah and Abu Dawood with two Sahih chains). And (the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to raise his hands with this Takbeer) sometimes. (Bukhari and Muslim). And he would do in this prostration the same as he did in the first. Then (he would raise his head saying Takbeer). (Abu Dawood; Al-Hakim authenticated it and Al-Dhahabi agreed). And he commanded (the one who prayed badly) to do so, saying to him after commanding him with the second prostration as passed: (Then he raises his head and says Takbeer). And he said to him: (Ahmed and Tirmidhi who authenticated it) ([Then do that in every Rak'ah and prostration]. If you do that, your prayer is complete, and if you decrease anything from it, you have decreased from your prayer). (Abu Awanah and Abu Dawood with two Sahih chains). And (he used to raise his hands) sometimes. The Sitting of Rest (Jalsat al-Istirahah) (Bukhari and Abu Dawood). Then (he would sit upright [on his left leg evenly until every bone returned to its place]).

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Al-Shafi'i and Bukhari). Then (the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) would rise, leaning on the ground, to the second Rak'ah). (Abu Ishaq). And (he used to [do 'ajin' i.e.] support himself on his hands [like a kneader of dough] when standing up). (Muslim and Abu Awanah). And (when the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) rose for the second Rak'ah, he would start with 'Al-hamdu lillah' and would not pause). And he would do in this Rak'ah the same as he did in the first, except that he would make it shorter than the first as previously mentioned.

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: The Sitting for Tashahhud (Nasa'i with a Sahih chain). Then the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to sit for Tashahhud after finishing the second Rak'ah. If the prayer was two Rak'ahs like Fajr, (he sat spreading his foot [Muftari-shan]) (Bukhari and Abu Dawood) (just as he sat between the two prostrations). And likewise (he would sit in the first Tashahhud) of the three or four Rak'ah prayers. (Abu Dawood and Al-Bayhaqi with a good chain). And he commanded (the one who prayed badly) to do so, saying to him:

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (So when you sit in the middle of the prayer, be calm and spread your left thigh, then perform Tashahhud). And Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) said: (Al-Tayalisi, Ahmed, and Ibn Abi Shaybah) (My bosom friend (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) forbade me from squatting like the squatting of a dog). (Muslim and Abu Awanah). And in another hadith: (He used to forbid the devil's heel [a specific way of sitting]). (Muslim and Abu Awanah). And (when he sat for Tashahhud, he placed his right palm on his right thigh (and in a narration: his knee) and placed his left palm on his left thigh (and in a narration: his knee) [spreading it upon it]). (Abu Dawood and Nasa'i with a Sahih chain). And (the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to place the edge of his right elbow on his right thigh). (Al-Bayhaqi and Al-Hakim who authenticated it and Al-Dhahabi agreed). And (he forbade a man who was sitting leaning on his left hand in prayer, saying: (It is the prayer of the Jews). And in a wording:

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Muslim and Abu Awanah). And (the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to spread his left palm on his left knee and clench all the fingers of his right palm and point with his finger that is next to the thumb [index finger] towards the Qiblah, and cast his gaze at it). (Muslim and Abu Awanah). And (when he pointed with his finger, he placed his thumb on his middle finger). (Abu Dawood, Nasa'i, Ibn Al-Jarud, and Ibn Hibban in his Sahih). And sometimes (he would make a ring with them). (Abu Dawood and Ibn Hibban in his Sahih). And (he used to raise his finger moving it, supplicating with it). And he said:

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Ahmed, Al-Bazzar, and Abu Ja'far) (It is harder on Satan than iron. Meaning: the index finger). (Ibn Abi Shaybah with a Hasan chain). And (the Companions of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to remind one another [correct each other]. Meaning: Pointing with the finger in supplication). (Nasa'i and Al-Bayhaqi with a Sahih chain). And (the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to do that in both Tashahhuds). And (he saw a man supplicating with two fingers, so he said: (Make it one, make it one).

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Muslim and Abu Awanah). Then (the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to recite the (Tahiyyah) in every two Rak'ahs). (Al-Bayhaqi with a good chain). And (the first thing he would speak when sitting was: (At-Tahiyyat lillah). (Bukhari and Muslim). And (if he forgot it in the first two Rak'ahs, he would perform prostration for forgetfulness). And he used to command it, saying: (Nasa'i, Ahmed, and Tabarani with a Sahih chain) (When you sit in every two Rak'ahs, say: At-Tahiyyat etc... and let one of you choose whatever supplication impresses him and supplicate to Allah Almighty and Glorious [with it]). And in a wording: (Say in every sitting: At-Tahiyyat). And he commanded (the one who prayed badly) with it also, as presented just now. (Bukhari and Muslim). And (the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to teach them the Tashahhud just as he taught them a Surah from the Quran). (Abu Dawood; Al-Hakim authenticated it and Al-Dhahabi agreed). And (the Sunnah is to say it silently).

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: And the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) taught them various types of wording for Tashahhud: 1 - (Bukhari and Muslim) (Tashahhud of Ibn Masud: He said: (The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) taught me the Tashahhud - [while] my palm was between his palms - just as he taught me a Surah from the Quran: (At-Tahiyyatu lillahi was-salawatu wat-tayyibat, as-salamu 'alayka ayyuhan-nabiyyu wa rahmatullahi wa barakatuh, as-salamu 'alayna wa 'ala 'ibadillahis-saliheen [for if he says that, it reaches every righteous servant in the heaven and earth]. Ash-hadu an la ilaha illa Allah wa ash-hadu anna Muhammadan 'abduhu wa rasuluh). [This was while he was among us; when he passed away, we said: As-salamu 'alan-nabiy (Peace be upon the Prophet)].

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 2 - (Muslim, Abu Awanah, and Al-Shafi'i) Tashahhud of Ibn Abbas: He said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to teach us the Tashahhud just as he taught us [a Surah from] the Quran. He used to say: (At-Tahiyyat al-mubarakat as-salawat at-tayyibat lillah, [as]-salamu 'alayka ayyuhan-nabiyyu wa rahmatullahi wa barakatuh, [as]-salamu 'alayna wa 'ala 'ibadillahis-saliheen. Ash-hadu an la ilaha illa Allah wa [ash-hadu] anna Muhammadan rasulullah. And in a narration: 'abduhu wa rasuluh).

book_title: The Description of the Prophet's Prayer (pbuh) from Takbeer to Tasleem as if You Were Seeing It
publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 3 - (Abu Dawood and Daraqutni who authenticated it) Tashahhud of Ibn Umar: From the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) that he said in the Tashahhud: (At-Tahiyyat lillah [wa] as-salawat [wa] at-tayyibat. As-salamu 'alayka ayyuhan-nabiyyu wa rahmatullah - Ibn Umar said: I added to it: wa barakatuh - As-salamu 'alayna wa 'ala 'ibadillahis-saliheen. Ash-hadu an la ilaha illa Allah - Ibn Umar said: I added to it: wahdahu la shareeka lah - wa ash-hadu anna Muhammadan 'abduhu wa rasuluh). 4 - (Muslim and Abu Awanah) Tashahhud of Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari: He said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (...And when he is sitting, let the first thing one of you says be: At-Tahiyyat at-tayyibat as-salawat lillah. As-salamu 'alayka ayyuhan-nabiyyu wa rahmatullahi wa barakatuh. As-salamu 'alayna wa 'ala 'ibadillahis-saliheen. Ash-hadu an la ilaha illa Allah [wahdahu la shareeka lah] wa ash-hadu anna Muhammadan 'abduhu wa rasuluh [seven phrases counting the greeting of prayer]). 5 - (Malik and Al-Bayhaqi with a Sahih chain) Tashahhud of Umar bin Al-Khattab: He (may Allah be pleased with him) used to teach people the Tashahhud while on the pulpit, saying: Say: (At-Tahiyyat lillah, az-zakiyat lillah, at-tayyibat [lillah]. As-salamu 'alayka...)

text: First Benefit: It is noticeable that most of these types of formulas for blessings upon him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) do not mention Ibrahim himself independently from his family (Al), but rather contain: (As You sent blessings upon the family [Al] of Ibrahim). The reason for this is that the 'Al' (family) of a man in the Arabic language includes the man himself, as it includes others who revert to him, as in His saying, the Exalted: {Indeed, Allah chose Adam and Noah and the family of Abraham and the family of Imran over the worlds} [Ali Imran: 33] and His saying: {Except the family of Lot; We saved them by dawn} [Al-Qamar: 34]. And from it is the saying of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): (O Allah, send blessings upon the family of Abu Awfa). Likewise is the term 'Ahl al-Bayt' (People of the House), as in His saying, the Exalted: {The mercy of Allah and His blessings be upon you, people of the house} [Hud: 73], for Ibrahim is included among them. (Sheikh Al-Islam) said: (For this reason, it came in most of the wordings: 'As You sent blessings upon the family of Ibrahim' and 'As...

text: ...You blessed the family of Ibrahim'. And in some of them came: 'Ibrahim' himself, because he is the origin in the prayer and charity, and the rest of his family only receive that subsequently. And in some of them, this and that were mentioned to draw attention to both). If you know that, then the question has become famous among scholars regarding the aspect of similarity in his saying: (As You sent blessings...) etc., because the established rule is that the one likened is less than the one likened to, but the reality here is the opposite, since Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) is better than Ibrahim, and the implication of him being better is that the requested blessings be better than every blessing that has occurred or will occur. Scholars have answered this with many answers you can see in 'Al-Fath' and 'Al-Jala', reaching about ten views, some weaker than others, except one view which is strong and was deemed good by Sheikh Al-Islam and Ibn Al-Qayyim. It is the view of the one who said: (The family of Ibrahim includes Prophets who have no equal in the family of Muhammad. So if the like of what Ibrahim and his family have - which includes Prophets - is requested for the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and his family, the family of Muhammad receive from that what befits them, for they do not reach the ranks of Prophets, and the surplus which belongs to the Prophets - including Ibrahim - remains for Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), so he obtains a distinctiveness that no one else obtains). Ibn Al-Qayyim said: (This is better than all that preceded. And better than it is to say: Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) is from the family of Ibrahim; rather, he is the best of the family of Ibrahim, as narrated by Ali bin Talhah from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with him) regarding His saying, the Exalted: {Indeed, Allah chose Adam and Noah and the family of Abraham and the family of Imran over the worlds} [Ali Imran: 33]. Ibn Abbas said: (Muhammad is from the family of Ibrahim). This is a text. If other Prophets who are descendants of Ibrahim are included in...

text: ...his family, then the inclusion of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) is more appropriate. So our saying: 'As You sent blessings upon the family of Ibrahim' covers the blessings upon him and upon all the Prophets from the descendants of Ibrahim. Then Allah the Exalted commanded us to send blessings upon him and upon his family specifically, to the extent that we sent blessings upon him along with the rest of the family of Ibrahim generally - and he is among them. His family receives from that what befits them, and all the rest remains for him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). He said: There is no doubt that the specific blessings for the family of Ibrahim, with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) among them, are more perfect than the blessings obtained for them without them. So for him is requested from the blessings this great matter which is better than what Ibrahim has definitively. Thus, the benefit of the simile and its running according to its principle becomes apparent, and that what is requested for him of blessings by this wording is greater than what is requested for him by other than it. For if the request by supplication is only for the like of the one likened to, and he has the most abundant share of it, he obtains from the requested likeness more than what Ibrahim and others have. Added to that is what he has from the one likened to of the share that no one else obtained. Thus, by this appears his virtue and honor over Ibrahim and over everyone in his family - including the Prophets - which is befitting of him. And this prayer becomes indicative of this preference and subordinate to it, and it is among its causes and implications. So may Allah send blessings upon him and upon his family and grant them much peace, and reward him on our behalf with the best He has rewarded a Prophet on behalf of his nation. O Allah, send blessings upon Muhammad and upon the family of Muhammad as You sent blessings upon the family of Ibrahim, Indeed You are Praiseworthy and Glorious. And bless Muhammad and the family of Muhammad as You blessed the family of Ibrahim, Indeed You are Praiseworthy and Glorious). Second Benefit: The noble reader sees that all these formulas, despite their varying types, contain blessings upon the family of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), his wives, and his offspring along with him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). Therefore, it is not from the Sunnah, nor is one fulfilling the Prophetic command, if one restricts oneself to saying: 'Allahumma salli 'ala Muhammad' only. Rather, one must bring one of these formulas completely as they came from him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). There is no difference in that between the first Tashahhud and the last. text: ...Al-Shafi'i in (Al-Umm) (1 / 102), where he said: (The Tashahhud in the first and second [sitting] is one wording that does not differ. And the meaning of my saying 'Tashahhud' is the Tashahhud and the prayer [blessings] upon the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him); one of them does not suffice without the other). As for the hadith: (He used not to increase in the two Rak'ahs [first sitting] more than the Tashahhud), it is a rejected (Munkar) hadith as I verified in (Al-Da'ifah) (5186). Indeed, among the wonders of this time and its scientific chaos is that some people dare - namely Professor Muhammad Is'af Al-Nashashibi in his book: (True Islam) - to deny the prayer upon the Family in the prayer upon him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), despite that being reported in the (Two Sahihs) and others from a group of Companions, including Ka'b bin Ujrah, Abu Hamid Al-Sa'idi, Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, Abu Mas'ud Al-Ansari, Abu Hurairah, and Talhah bin Ubaidullah. In their hadiths, they asked the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): (How do we send blessings upon you?) So he taught them these formulas. His argument for denial is that Allah the Exalted did not mention anyone else with the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in His saying: {Send blessings upon him and greet him with peace}. Then he denied and exaggerated in denial that the Companions asked him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) that question, because the meaning of 'Salah' (prayer/blessings) was known to them, which is supplication, so how could they ask him? This is an exposed fallacy, because their question was not about the meaning of sending blessings upon him so that what he mentioned would apply, but rather it was about the *method* (how-to) of sending blessings upon him as came in all narrations as previously indicated. Thus, there is no strangeness, for they asked him about a legislative method that they could not know except through the Wise and All-Knowing Lawgiver. This is just as if they asked him about the method of the obligatory Prayer based on His saying: {And establish the Prayer}. For their knowledge of the original meaning of 'Salah' in the language does not dispense with their need to ask about its legislative method. This is clear and not hidden.

text: As for his indicated argument, it is worthless. Because it is known among Muslims that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) is the clarifier of the Speech of the Lord of the Worlds, as He, the Exalted, said: {And We revealed to you the message that you may make clear to the people what was sent down to them} [Al-Nahl: 44]. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) clarified the method of sending blessings upon him, and in it is the mention of the Family, so accepting that from him is obligatory due to His saying, the Exalted: {And whatever the Messenger has given you - take; and what he has forbidden you - refrain from} [Al-Hashr: 7], and his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in the famous Sahih hadith: (Verily I have been given the Quran and the like of it with it). It is referenced in (Takhreej Al-Mishkat) (163 and 4247). I wonder what Al-Nashashibi - and whoever might be deceived by his flashy words - says about one who might deny the Tashahhud in prayer or deny the menstruating woman leaving prayer and fasting during her menses, claiming that Allah did not mention Tashahhud in the Quran but only mentioned standing, bowing, and prostrating, and that He did not drop prayer and fasting from the menstruating woman in the Quran, so she must perform them? Do they agree with this denier in his denial or do they rebuke him? If it is the first - and that is what we do not hope for - then they have strayed far and left the consensus of Muslims. And if it is the latter, then they have been guided and correct. Whatever they reply to that denier is our reply to Al-Nashashibi. We have shown you the face of that. So beware, O Muslim, of trying to understand the Quran independently of the Sunnah, for you will never be able to do that, even if you were the Sibawayh (master grammarian) of your time. Here is the example before you; for this Al-Nashashibi was among the senior scholars of language in the present century, yet you see he went astray when he was deceived by his knowledge of language and did not seek help in understanding the Quran from the Sunnah; rather, he denied it as you knew. Therefore, later scholars differed regarding the legitimacy of adding it in the Ibrahimic Prayers. The space does not allow detailing the discussion on that now. Those who held the view of not legitimizing it mentioned following the perfect instruction of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to his nation when he was asked about the method of sending blessings upon him, so he answered commanding with his saying: (Say: Allahumma salli 'ala Muhammad...). However, I want to convey to the noble readers here the opinion of Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar Al-Asqalani on that, considering him one of the senior Shafi'i scholars who combined Hadith and Fiqh. For contrary to this noble Prophetic instruction has become widespread among the later Shafi'is. Al-Hafiz Muhammad bin Muhammad bin Muhammad Al-Ghurabili (790 - 835) - who was a close student of Ibn Hajar - said (may Allah have mercy on him), and from his handwriting I copied: (And (i.e., Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar) - may Allah allow us to benefit from his life - was asked about the description of the blessings upon the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in the prayer or outside the prayer, whether it is said to be obligatory or recommended: Is it a condition in it to describe him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) with Siyadah (Mastery), such as saying for example: 'Allahumma salli 'ala Sayyidina Muhammad' or 'ala Sayyid al-Khalq' or 'ala Sayyid Walad Adam', or should one restrict oneself to saying: 'Allahumma salli 'ala Muhammad'? And which is better: bringing the word of Siyadah because it is a fixed attribute for him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), or not bringing it due to the absence of that in the narrations? He answered (may Allah be pleased with him): Yes, following the narrated wordings is weightier. And it should not be said: Perhaps he left that out of humility...

text: ...from him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), just as he did not use to say when mentioning himself: 'Sallallahu alayhi wa sallam', while his nation is encouraged to say that whenever he is mentioned. For we say: If that were weightier, it would have come from the Companions, then from the Successors. But we have not found in any of the narrations from any of the Companions or the Successors to them that he said that, despite the abundance of what was narrated from them regarding that. And this is Imam Al-Shafi'i - may Allah raise his rank - who is among the people who most venerated the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him); he said in the introduction of his book which is the pillar of the people of his school: (Allahumma salli 'ala Muhammad) to the end of what his Ijtihad led him to, which is his saying: 'Whenever the rememberers remember him and whenever the heedless are heedless of his remembrance'. It is as if he derived that from the Sahih hadith which contains: (Glory be to Allah by the number of His creation). For it is established that he (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said to the Mother of the Believers - seeing she had done much Tasbeeh and prolonged it -: (I have said after you words that if they were weighed against what you said, they would outweigh them). So he mentioned that. And the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to like comprehensive supplications. Judge Iyad devoted a chapter to the description of the blessings upon the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in the book (Al-Shifa) and cited therein traces raised (Marfu') from a group of Companions and Successors; in none of them from any of the Companions or others is the word: (Sayyidina). Among them is the hadith of Ali that he used to teach them the method of blessings upon the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), saying: 'O Allah, Spreader of the Expanses and Creator of the Heavens, place Your foremost blessings and growing favors and increasing greetings upon Muhammad, Your servant and Messenger, the Opener of what was closed.' And from Ali that he used to say: 'The blessings of Allah, the Kind and Merciful, and the Angels brought near, and the Prophets, the Truthful, the Martyrs, and the Righteous, and whatever has glorified You, O Lord of the Worlds, be upon Muhammad bin Abdullah, the Seal of the Prophets and Imam of the God-fearing...' text: ...and Your favors and Your mercy upon Muhammad, Your servant and Messenger, the Imam of Good and Messenger of Mercy...' The Hadith. And from Al-Hasan Al-Basri that he used to say: 'Whoever wants to drink from the fullest cup from the Basin of the Chosen One, let him say: O Allah, send blessings upon Muhammad and upon his family, his companions, his wives, his children, his offspring, his household, his in-laws, his helpers, his followers, and his lovers.' This is what I prefer from (Al-Shifa) regarding the form of blessings upon him from the Companions and those after them. He mentioned other than that in it. Yes, it was reported in the hadith of Ibn Masud that he used to say in his blessings upon the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'O Allah, place the virtues of Your blessings, Your mercy, and Your favors upon the Master of the Messengers (Sayyid Al-Mursalin)...' The Hadith. Ibn Majah narrated it, but its chain is weak. And the hadith of Ali referred to first was narrated by Al-Tabarani with a chain that is not bad, and it contains strange words which I narrated explained in the book (The Virtue of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him)) by Abu Al-Hasan bin Al-Faris. The Shafi'is mentioned that if a man swore an oath to send the best blessings upon the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), the way to fulfill the oath is to send blessings upon the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) [saying]: 'Allahumma salli 'ala Muhammad kullama dhakarahu adh-dhakiroon wa saha 'an dhikrihi al-ghafiloon'. And Al-Nawawi said: The correct view which should be asserted is to say: 'Allahumma salli 'ala Muhammad wa 'ala aali Muhammad kama sallayta 'ala Ibrahim...' The Hadith. A group of later scholars critiqued this, saying there is nothing in the two mentioned methods indicating established superiority in them in terms of transmission. As for meaning, the superiority is apparent in the first. The issue is famous in the books of Fiqh. I say: What Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar (may Allah have mercy on him) held regarding the lack of legitimacy of addressing him as Sayyid (Master) in the prayer upon him, in adherence to the noble Command - which is the position of the Hanafis - is what should be held onto, because it is the truthful proof of loving him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). {Say, 'If you should love Allah, then follow me, [so] Allah will love you'} [Ali Imran: 31]. For that reason, Imam Al-Nawawi said in (Al-Rawdah) (1 / 265): (And the most perfect blessings upon the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) is: Allahumma salli 'ala Muhammad...) etc., according to the third type mentioned previously, and he did not mention (Al-Siyadah) in it. Fourth Benefit: Know that the first type of the formulas for blessings upon him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) - as well as the fourth type - is what the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) taught his Companions when they asked him about the method of sending blessings upon him. This has been used as evidence that it is the best of methods for sending blessings upon him, because he would not choose for them - nor for himself - except the most noble and best. Hence, Al-Nawawi considered it correct in (Al-Rawdah) that if one swore to send the best blessings upon him, he would not fulfill the oath except with that method. Al-Subki justified this by saying that whoever uses it has sent blessings upon the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) with certainty, and whoever uses a wording other than it, his performance of the requested blessings is in doubt, because they said: 'How do we send blessings upon you?' He said: (Say:...), so he made the blessings upon him from them to be their saying such-and-such. Ended. Al-Haytami mentioned it in (Al-Durr Al-Mandud) (Folio 25/2). Then they mentioned (Folio 27/1) that the objective is achieved by any of these methods that came in the authentic Hadiths.

text: Fifth Benefit: Know that it is not legislated to fabricate one formula of blessings from the combination of these formulas. The same is said regarding the formulas of Tashahhud mentioned previously. Rather, that is an innovation in the religion. The Sunnah is to say this one sometimes and that one sometimes, as clarified by Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah in a research of his regarding Takbeer in the two Eids (Majmu') (69 / 253 / 1). Sixth Benefit: The scholar Siddiq Hasan Khan said in his book (Nuzul Al-Abrar bil-'Ilm Al-Ma'thur min Al-Ad'iyah wal-Adhkar) after citing many hadiths regarding the virtue of sending blessings upon the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and doing so frequently - he said (p. 161): (There is no doubt that the Muslims who send the most blessings upon him are the People of Hadith (Ahl al-Hadith) and the narrators of the pure Sunnah. For among their duties in this noble science is sending blessings upon him before every hadith, and their tongues remain moist with his mention (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). There is no book among the books of Sunnah nor a collection among the collections of Hadith - with their varying types like (Jawami'), (Masanid), (Ma'ajim), (Ajza'), and others - except that it contains thousands of hadiths. Even the most concise of them in volume, the book (Al-Jami' Al-Saghir) by Al-Suyuti, contains ten thousand hadiths. Measure against that the rest of the Prophetic scrolls. So this Saved Group and Hadith Community are the closest of people to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) on the Day of Resurrection and the most fortunate with his intercession (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) - may my father and mother be sacrificed for him. No one among the people equals them in this virtue except one who brings better than what they brought, and below that is the stripping of thorns [an impossible task]. So upon you, O seeker of good and seeker of salvation without harm, is to be a Muhaddith (Hadith scholar) or attached to the Muhaddithin, otherwise do not be... for there is no benefit returning to you in other than that). I say: And I ask Allah, the Blessed and Exalted, to make me among these Muhaddithin who are the closest of people to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). Perhaps this book is among the evidences for that.

text: Conclusion: All that has preceded regarding the description of his prayer (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) applies equally to men and women. There is nothing in the Sunnah that necessitates exempting women from some of that. Rather, the generality of his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): (Pray as you have seen me pray) includes them. This is the saying of Ibrahim Al-Nakha'i, who said: (The woman does in the prayer just as the man does). Ibn Abi Shaybah narrated it (1 / 75 / 2) with a Sahih chain from him. As for the hadith about the woman gathering herself together in prostration and that she is not like the man in that, it is Mursal (disconnected) and not a proof. Abu Dawood narrated it in (Al-Marasil) (117 / 87) from Yazid bin Abi Habib, and it is referenced in (Al-Da'ifah) (2652). As for what Imam Ahmed narrated in (Masail of his son Abdullah from him) (p. 71) from Ibn Umar that he used to command his women to sit cross-legged in prayer, its chain is not authentic because it contains Abdullah bin Al-Umari who is weak. And Bukhari narrated in (Al-Tarikh Al-Saghir) (p. 95) with a Sahih chain from Umm Al-Darda: (That she used to sit in her prayer the sitting of a man, and she was a jurist). This is the last of what was easy to collect regarding the description of the prayer of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) from Takbeer to Tasleem. I ask Allah the Exalted to make it purely for His Noble Face and a guide to the Sunnah of His Prophet, the Compassionate, the Merciful.
